clusters.title: Acting ICE director says Dallas shooting will shift security protocols
clusters.neutral_headline: Dallas ICE Facility Shooting: One Dead, Two Injured

items.title: Acting ICE director says Dallas shooting will shift security protocols
items.standfirst: At least one person is dead and two more are injured after a man opened fire on an Immigration and Customs Enforcement field office in Dallas on Wednesday. CBS News' Camilo Montoya-Galvez sat down with acting ICE director Todd Lyons to discuss.
items.content: At least one person is dead and two more are injured after a man opened fire on an Immigration and Customs Enforcement field office in Dallas on Wednesday. CBS News' Camilo Montoya-Galvez sat down with acting ICE director Todd Lyons to discuss.

items.title: Shooter attacks ICE facility in Dallas, Texas, killing one detainee
items.standfirst: The Department of Homeland Security announced on Wednesday that a man with a rifle opened fire on a Dallas, Texas Immigration and Customs Enforcement location. This comes in the wake of increased border patrol measures, and a number of retaliatory attacks on ICE agents.
items.content: The Department of Homeland Security announced on Wednesday that a man with a rifle opened fire on a Dallas, Texas Immigration and Customs Enforcement location. This comes in the wake of increased border patrol measures, and a number of retaliatory attacks on ICE agents.

items.title: FBI investigating Dallas ICE facility shooting as "targeted attack"
items.standfirst: The Department of Homeland Security said at least one person was killed and two others were injured after a gunman opened fire on an ICE field office in Dallas Wednesday. CBS News Homeland Security correspondent Nicole Sganga reports.
items.content: The Department of Homeland Security said at least one person was killed and two others were injured after a gunman opened fire on an ICE field office in Dallas Wednesday. CBS News Homeland Security correspondent Nicole Sganga reports.

items.title: Acting ICE Director Todd Lyons reacts to Dallas shooting, says attack targeted law enforcement
items.standfirst: A gunman opened fire at an Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Dallas, Texas, on Wednesday, killing at least one and critically injuring two others. CBS News immigration and politics reporter Camilo Montoya-Galvez spoke with acting ICE Director Todd Lyons about the attack.
items.content: A gunman opened fire at an Immigration and Customs Enforcement facility in Dallas, Texas, on Wednesday, killing at least one and critically injuring two others. CBS News immigration and politics reporter Camilo Montoya-Galvez spoke with acting ICE Director Todd Lyons about the attack.

items.title: 'Anti-ICE' message on ammunition at Dallas shooting that killed immigration detainee
items.standfirst: The gunman fired at an unmarked van near the detention facility, before taking his own life, officials say.
items.content: The gunman fired at an unmarked van near the detention facility, before taking his own life, officials say.

items.title: Deadly shooting at Dallas ICE facility investigated by FBI as targeted attack
items.standfirst: One person was killed and two people are in critical condition after a shooting at a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) field office in Dallas, authorities said.
items.content: One person was killed and two people are in critical condition after a shooting at a U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) field office in Dallas, authorities said.

items.title: Texas Ice facility shooting: what we know so far about deadly attack
items.standfirst: One detainee was killed and two were critically wounded in shooting the White House says is ‘politically motivated’Texas Ice facility shooting – latest updatesTexas Ice facility shooting: Republicans blame ‘radical left’ as Democrats focus on victims and gun controlA gunman fired at a Dallas immigration field office on Wednesday, killing one detainee and critically wounding two more, before killing himself in what authorities called an indiscriminate attack on US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice).Here’s what we know about the attack so far:One detainee has been killed, with two others in critical condition. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) said previously that two detainees had been killed and one injured, but issued a corrected statement. The Dallas police chief, Daniel Comeaux, said that the FBI is investigating the incident as an act of targeted violence. The shooter died from a “self-inflicted gun wound”, according to the secretary of the DHS, Kristi Noem.The DHS said no members of law enforcement were hurt in the attack. But Comeaux also said that officials would not be releasing the identities of any victims at this time.DHS officials say this was “an attack on Ice law enforcement”. At both today’s press conference and in a statement, law enforcement said that shell casings found near the shooter had “anti-Ice” messaging on them.The shooter has been identified as 29-year-old Joshua Jahn, according to NBC News – which cited several senior law enforcement officials.Dallas police said that shots were fired “from an adjacent building”. The DHS later added that the shooter “fired indiscriminately” at the Ice facility, “including at a van in the sallyport where the victims were shot”. All three victims were inside the van at the time the gunman opened fire.The Dallas field office where the shooting occurred is used for short-term processing of people in custody. The victims may have been recently arrested by Ice. The facility is along Interstate 35 East, south-west of a large commercial airport serving the Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area, and just blocks from hotels catering to airport travelers.Despite the fact that no federal agents were wounded in the shooting, the Texas governor, Greg Abbott, called the attack an “assassination”. For her part, Noem said that “these horrendous killings must serve as a wake-up call to the far left that their rhetoric about Ice has consequences”. Donald Trump instantly politicized the shooting, claiming in a social media post that it “is the result of the Radical Left Democrats constantly demonizing Law Enforcement, calling for ICE to be demolished, and comparing ICE Officers to ‘Nazis.’”The vice-president, JD Vance, claimed without evidence that the shooting was carried out by “a violent leftwing extremist” who was “politically motivated to go after law enforcement”. While the FBI has said that authorities recovered shell casings with “anti-Ice messaging” near the shooter, officials have neither confirmed a motive nor corroborated Vance’s claims about the shooter’s ideological background. Continue reading...
items.content: One detainee was killed and two were critically wounded in shooting the White House says is ‘politically motivated’Texas Ice facility shooting – latest updatesTexas Ice facility shooting: Republicans blame ‘radical left’ as Democrats focus on victims and gun controlA gunman fired at a Dallas immigration field office on Wednesday, killing one detainee and critically wounding two more, before killing himself in what authorities called an indiscriminate attack on US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice).Here’s what we know about the attack so far:One detainee has been killed, with two others in critical condition. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) said previously that two detainees had been killed and one injured, but issued a corrected statement. The Dallas police chief, Daniel Comeaux, said that the FBI is investigating the incident as an act of targeted violence. The shooter died from a “self-inflicted gun wound”, according to the secretary of the DHS, Kristi Noem.The DHS said no members of law enforcement were hurt in the attack. But Comeaux also said that officials would not be releasing the identities of any victims at this time.DHS officials say this was “an attack on Ice law enforcement”. At both today’s press conference and in a statement, law enforcement said that shell casings found near the shooter had “anti-Ice” messaging on them.The shooter has been identified as 29-year-old Joshua Jahn, according to NBC News – which cited several senior law enforcement officials.Dallas police said that shots were fired “from an adjacent building”. The DHS later added that the shooter “fired indiscriminately” at the Ice facility, “including at a van in the sallyport where the victims were shot”. All three victims were inside the van at the time the gunman opened fire.The Dallas field office where the shooting occurred is used for short-term processing of people in custody. The victims may have been recently arrested by Ice. The facility is along Interstate 35 East, south-west of a large commercial airport serving the Dallas-Fort Worth metropolitan area, and just blocks from hotels catering to airport travelers.Despite the fact that no federal agents were wounded in the shooting, the Texas governor, Greg Abbott, called the attack an “assassination”. For her part, Noem said that “these horrendous killings must serve as a wake-up call to the far left that their rhetoric about Ice has consequences”. Donald Trump instantly politicized the shooting, claiming in a social media post that it “is the result of the Radical Left Democrats constantly demonizing Law Enforcement, calling for ICE to be demolished, and comparing ICE Officers to ‘Nazis.’”The vice-president, JD Vance, claimed without evidence that the shooting was carried out by “a violent leftwing extremist” who was “politically motivated to go after law enforcement”. While the FBI has said that authorities recovered shell casings with “anti-Ice messaging” near the shooter, officials have neither confirmed a motive nor corroborated Vance’s claims about the shooter’s ideological background. Continue reading...

items.title: Texas Ice facility shooting: Republicans blame ‘radical left’ as Democrats focus on victims and gun control
items.standfirst: Democrats say Trump allies are using incident for ‘political points’ against the left despite the victims being detaineesA deadly shooting at a US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) field office in Dallas has been met with markedly different reactions from the political right and left.The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) confirmed shortly after the news broke that detainees were the victims of the sniper attack on the facility and that no federal agents had been injured. The president and his allies, however, were quick to frame the shooting as an attack on Ice and place blame on the “radical left”. Continue reading...
items.content: Democrats say Trump allies are using incident for ‘political points’ against the left despite the victims being detaineesA deadly shooting at a US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) field office in Dallas has been met with markedly different reactions from the political right and left.The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) confirmed shortly after the news broke that detainees were the victims of the sniper attack on the facility and that no federal agents had been injured. The president and his allies, however, were quick to frame the shooting as an attack on Ice and place blame on the “radical left”. Continue reading...

items.title: Dallas ICE office targeted in deadly shooting faced bomb threat last month
items.standfirst: The Immigration and Customs Enforcement field office where a gunman opened fire on Wednesday was also the target of an alleged bomb threat in August.

items.title: Gunman fires on US immigration facility in Texas, killing at least two
items.standfirst: A gunman reportedly opened fired on a federal immigration facility in Dallas, Texas.
items.content: A gunman reportedly opened fired on a federal immigration facility in Dallas, Texas.

items.title: Shooting at ICE detention facility in Dallas kills 1 detainee, injures 2 others
items.standfirst: Authorities are investigating a fatal shooting Wednesday at a federal immigration detention facility in Dallas. One detainee was killed in what the FBI says was an act "of targeted violence."
items.content: Authorities are investigating a fatal shooting Wednesday at a federal immigration detention facility in Dallas. One detainee was killed in what the FBI says was an act "of targeted violence."(Image credit: Aric Becker)

ai_summary: A gunman opened fire at a Dallas ICE field office, resulting in one fatality and two injuries.
The FBI is investigating the shooting as a targeted attack on the ICE facility.
Acting ICE Director Todd Lyons stated the attack targeted law enforcement personnel.
The shooter fired at an unmarked van near the facility before taking their own life.
The Department of Homeland Security confirmed the shooting and ongoing investigation.

items.title: Yemen drone attack wounds dozens in southern Israeli city of Eilat
items.standfirst: A drone launched from Yemen struck Israel's southern resort city of Eilat on Wednesday, wounding at least 20 people, according to rescuers. While no group immediately claimed responsibility, Yemen’s Iran-backed Houthi rebels have carried out repeated attacks on Israel during the Gaza war.

While no group immediately claimed responsibility, Yemen’s Iran-backed Houthi rebels have carried out repeated attacks on Israel during the Gaza war.

items.content: At least 20 people were injured on Wednesday after a drone launched from Yemen hit Israel’s Red Sea resort city of Eilat on the border with Jordan and Egypt, the Israeli national ambulance service Magen David Adom said

The drone hit a hotel in Eilat, causing damage in a tourist-frequented area.

The attack occurred during the Gaza war, with no immediate claim of responsibility.

clusters.title: Putin wants to expand war beyond Ukraine, Zelenskyy warns U.N.
clusters.neutral_headline: Zelenskyy Warns of Expanded War, Global Arms Race

items.title: Putin wants to expand war beyond Ukraine, Zelenskyy warns U.N.
items.standfirst: In his address to the U.N. General Assembly on Wednesday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy warned that Russia wants to expand the war beyond Ukraine. CBS News reporter Olivia Gazis has more.
items.content: In his address to the U.N. General Assembly on Wednesday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy warned that Russia wants to expand the war beyond Ukraine. CBS News reporter Olivia Gazis has more.

items.title: 'A speech calculated to appeal to Trump and the Global South'
items.standfirst: Reporting from Kyiv, FRANCE 24's correspondent Gulliver Cragg says Volodymyr Zelenskyy's speech at the United Nations General Assembly was one very much calculated to please US President Donald Trump and 'to appeal to the Global South, to people who are far from Europe but might think that this war in Ukraine poses a threat to them in ways they hadn't perhaps previously imagined'.
items.content: Reporting from Kyiv, FRANCE 24's correspondent Gulliver Cragg says Volodymyr Zelenskyy's speech at the United Nations General Assembly was one very much calculated to please US President Donald Trump and 'to appeal to the Global South, to people who are far from Europe but might think that this war in Ukraine poses a threat to them in ways they hadn't perhaps previously imagined'.

items.title: Ukraine’s president says the world is in `the most destructive arms race in human history’
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told global leaders Wednesday that the world is in “the most destructive arms race in human history” and urged the international community to act against Russia now, asserting that Vladimir Putin wants to expand his war in Europe. FRANCE 24's Carys Garland reports.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy told global leaders Wednesday that the world is in “the most destructive arms race in human history” and urged the international community to act against Russia now, asserting that Vladimir Putin wants to expand his war in Europe. FRANCE 24's Carys Garland reports.

items.title: Russia will expand aggression beyond Ukraine if not stopped, Zelensky warns
items.standfirst: Vladimir Putin "will keep driving the war forward wider and deeper", the Ukrainian president tells the UN.
items.content: Vladimir Putin "will keep driving the war forward wider and deeper", the Ukrainian president tells the UN.

items.title: Ukraine's Zelenskyy issues a stark warning about a global arms race and AI war
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addressed the U.N. General Assembly a day after President Trump made another shift in his stance on Russia's war in Ukraine.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addressed the U.N. General Assembly a day after President Trump made another shift in his stance on Russia's war in Ukraine.(Image credit: Richard Drew)

items.title: Zelenskyy's UN speech was in perfect English - and served as a warning
items.standfirst: Volodymyr Zelenskyy's moment in the United Nations General Assembly chamber came a day after he told Sky News that Donald Trump's language represented a "big shift" in America's stance on Ukraine.
items.content: Volodymyr Zelenskyy's moment in the United Nations General Assembly chamber came a day after he told Sky News that Donald Trump's language represented a "big shift" in America's stance on Ukraine.

ai_summary: Ukrainian President Zelenskyy warned the UN that Russia aims to expand the war.
Zelenskyy stated the world is in the most destructive arms race in human history.
He urged the international community to act against Russia's aggression.
Zelenskyy's speech was delivered in perfect English, serving as a warning.
Zelenskyy's address followed a shift in stance by former President Trump.

clusters.title: Deadly Super Typhoon Ragasa kills at least 17 people
clusters.neutral_headline: Typhoon Ragasa Kills at Least 17, Hits China

items.title: Deadly Super Typhoon Ragasa kills at least 17 people
items.standfirst: Super Typhoon Ragasa is barreling through Asia, slamming Hong Kong with heavy rain and winds. The storm has closed schools and businesses. Taiwanese officials say at least 17 people have died and many are missing. NBC News’ Janis Mackey Frayer reports.
items.content: Super Typhoon Ragasa is barreling through Asia, slamming Hong Kong with heavy rain and winds. The storm has closed schools and businesses. Taiwanese officials say at least 17 people have died and many are missing. NBC News’ Janis Mackey Frayer reports.

items.title: Deadly Typhoon Ragasa leaves path of destruction in east Asia
items.standfirst: Typhoon Ragasa, the most powerful tropical storm on Earth this year, hammered southern China after killing at least 20 people in the Philippines and Taiwan. NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer has more on the deadly storm.
items.content: Typhoon Ragasa, the most powerful tropical storm on Earth this year, hammered southern China after killing at least 20 people in the Philippines and Taiwan. NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer has more on the deadly storm.

items.title: As it happened – deadly cyclone makes landfall in China after devastating Hong Kong, Taiwan and Philippines

Continue reading...

items.title: Typhoon Ragasa makes landfall in China after 17 killed in Taiwan
items.standfirst: Ragasa is the world's strongest storm this year and has been roaring over the South China Sea for days.
items.content: Ragasa is the world's strongest storm this year and has been roaring over the South China Sea for days.

items.title: Super Typhoon Ragasa: 17 killed in Taiwan and Hong Kong battered as storm hits China
items.standfirst: Chinese businesses and schools shut and residents in high-rises ordered to evacuate as storm makes landfall on Guangdong coastSuper Typhoon Ragasa – latest updatesFierce winds, pounding rain and high seas battered Hong Kong as Super Typhoon Ragasa headed into southern China after causing a lake to burst in Taiwan, killing at least 17 people.Hong Kong experienced widespread damage on Wednesday, including fallen trees and flooding in many areas, with the storm surge smashing the glass doors of an upmarket hotel and flooding its lobby, according to footage circulating online. Continue reading...
items.content: Chinese businesses and schools shut and residents in high-rises ordered to evacuate as storm makes landfall on Guangdong coastSuper Typhoon Ragasa – latest updatesFierce winds, pounding rain and high seas battered Hong Kong as Super Typhoon Ragasa headed into southern China after causing a lake to burst in Taiwan, killing at least 17 people.Hong Kong experienced widespread damage on Wednesday, including fallen trees and flooding in many areas, with the storm surge smashing the glass doors of an upmarket hotel and flooding its lobby, according to footage circulating online. Continue reading...

items.title: Super typhoon slams into Hong Kong after killing at least 17 in Taiwan
items.standfirst: Streets in southern China were deserted on Wednesday as Typhoon Ragasa, one of the world’s strongest storms this year, slammed into the region after carving a deadly path between the Philippines and Taiwan.
items.content: Streets in southern China were deserted on Wednesday as Typhoon Ragasa, one of the world’s strongest storms this year, slammed into the region after carving a deadly path between the Philippines and Taiwan.

items.title: Super typhoon hits China and Hong Kong after 17 killed in Taiwan
items.standfirst: At least 17 people have been killed in an area of Taiwan popular with tourists after super typhoon Ragasa lashed the island nation, with Hong Kong and mainland China also impacted.
items.content: At least 17 people have been killed in an area of Taiwan popular with tourists after super typhoon Ragasa lashed the island nation, with Hong Kong and mainland China also impacted.

ai_summary: Super Typhoon Ragasa caused at least 17 deaths in Taiwan and Hong Kong.
The storm is the strongest of 2025 and made landfall in southern China.
Hong Kong experienced widespread damage, including flooding and fallen trees.
Businesses and schools in China were shut down due to the typhoon.
The storm battered Hong Kong after devastating Taiwan and the Philippines.

clusters.title: Denmark airport closed due to drones, two days after incursions in Copenhagen and Oslo
clusters.neutral_headline: Denmark Airport Closed Due to Drone Sightings

items.title: Denmark airport closed due to drones, two days after incursions in Copenhagen and Oslo
items.standfirst: Police said the drones over Aalborg airport followed a similar pattern to the ones that had halted flights at Copenhagen airport a few days earlierDenmark’s Aalborg airport was closed due to drones in its airspace, local police said early on Thursday, two days after the country’s main Copenhagen airport was shut over drone sightings that rattled European aviation.Danish national police said the drones followed a similar pattern to the ones that had halted flights at Copenhagen airport for four hours a few days earlier. The country’s armed forces were also affected, as Aalborg airport is used as a military base, they added. Continue reading...
items.content: Police said the drones over Aalborg airport followed a similar pattern to the ones that had halted flights at Copenhagen airport a few days earlierDenmark’s Aalborg airport was closed due to drones in its airspace, local police said early on Thursday, two days after the country’s main Copenhagen airport was shut over drone sightings that rattled European aviation.Danish national police said the drones followed a similar pattern to the ones that had halted flights at Copenhagen airport for four hours a few days earlier. The country’s armed forces were also affected, as Aalborg airport is used as a military base, they added. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Aalborg airport in Denmark closed due to drone sightings in its airspace.
The drone activity followed a similar pattern to incidents at Copenhagen airport.
Copenhagen airport was previously shut down for four hours due to drones.
The Danish national police confirmed the drone sightings near Aalborg Airport.
Aalborg airport is also used as a military base, affecting armed forces.

clusters.title: China announces plans to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions
clusters.neutral_headline: China Announces Plans to Reduce Emissions

items.title: China announces plans to significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions
items.standfirst: At a climate leaders' summit at the United Nations on Wednesday, Chinese President Xi Jinping announced that China would reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 7-10%, and increase consumption of non-fossil fuels domestically. Xi discouraged developed nations from "going against the trend" of climate action, merely a day after Trump called climate change a "con job."
items.content: At a climate leaders' summit at the United Nations on Wednesday, Chinese President Xi Jinping announced that China would reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 7-10%, and increase consumption of non-fossil fuels domestically. Xi discouraged developed nations from "going against the trend" of climate action, merely a day after Trump called climate change a "con job."

items.title: China plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by up to 10% by 2035, Xi tells UN
items.standfirst: Chinese President Xi Jinping on Wednesday told the United Nations that by 2035, his country plans to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 7 per cent to 10 per cent below its peak emissions, and called out “some countries” for moving against the global clean energy transition. Xi addressed a…
items.content: Chinese President Xi Jinping on Wednesday told the United Nations that by 2035, his country plans to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 7 per cent to 10 per cent below its peak emissions, and called out “some countries” for moving against the global clean energy transition. Xi addressed a…

items.title: ‘Science demands action’: world leaders and UN push climate agenda forward despite Trump’s attacks
items.standfirst: Leaders unveil new targets to cut planet-heating pollution after Trump called climate crisis a ‘con job’World leaders have unveiled new targets to cut planet-heating pollution at the United Nations, in a bid to spur fresh impetus to the beleaguered climate effort a day after Donald Trump called the crisis “the greatest con job ever perpetrated upon the world”.A total of 120 countries and the European Union announced new goals to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions in New York on Wednesday. The pledges most notably include one from China, the world’s leading emitter, which said it would cut emissions by 7-10% from its peak level by 2035. Continue reading...
items.content: Leaders unveil new targets to cut planet-heating pollution after Trump called climate crisis a ‘con job’World leaders have unveiled new targets to cut planet-heating pollution at the United Nations, in a bid to spur fresh impetus to the beleaguered climate effort a day after Donald Trump called the crisis “the greatest con job ever perpetrated upon the world”.A total of 120 countries and the European Union announced new goals to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions in New York on Wednesday. The pledges most notably include one from China, the world’s leading emitter, which said it would cut emissions by 7-10% from its peak level by 2035. Continue reading...

ai_summary: China announced plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 7-10% by 2035.
The announcement was made at a UN climate leaders' summit.
Xi Jinping called out countries moving against the clean energy transition.
The announcement followed Trump's statement calling climate change a "con job."
120 countries and the EU announced new goals to reduce emissions.

clusters.title: First migrants arrive in UK from France under 'one in one out' deal

items.title: First migrants arrive in UK from France under 'one in one out' deal
items.standfirst: A family of three are the first people to be allowed into the country from France, the Home Office says.
items.content: A family of three are the first people to be allowed into the country from France, the Home Office says.

items.title: Family of three are first arrivals in UK under ‘one in, one out’ immigration deal
items.standfirst: Small child part of first reciprocal intake after removal of four asylum seekers from Britain to France over past weekA family of three including a small child have become the first arrivals from France under Keir Starmer’s “one in, one out” deal, the Home Office has said.The move follows the removal on Wednesday of the first four asylum seekers from the UK to France over the past six days, despite continuing legal challenges. Continue reading...
items.content: Small child part of first reciprocal intake after removal of four asylum seekers from Britain to France over past weekA family of three including a small child have become the first arrivals from France under Keir Starmer’s “one in, one out” deal, the Home Office has said.The move follows the removal on Wednesday of the first four asylum seekers from the UK to France over the past six days, despite continuing legal challenges. Continue reading...

items.title: First migrants arrive in UK under 'one in, one out' deal

items.content: The first family has arrived in the UK under Prime Minister Keir Starmer's 'one in, one out' deal with France.

ai_summary: A family of three arrived in the UK from France under a new immigration deal.
The deal involves a "one in, one out" reciprocal agreement.
The arrivals followed the removal of four asylum seekers from the UK to France.
The Home Office confirmed the family's arrival as the first under the deal.
The deal was established under Prime Minister Keir Starmer's leadership.

items.title: China announces new climate goal to cut its world-leading emissions
items.standfirst: The world’s largest carbon polluting nation has announced a new climate fighting goal to cut emissions by 7% to 10% by 2035.
items.content: The world’s largest carbon polluting nation has announced a new climate fighting goal to cut emissions by 7% to 10% by 2035.

clusters.title: Key takeaways from Jimmy Kimmel's first show since suspension
clusters.neutral_headline: Key Takeaways from Jimmy Kimmel's First Show

items.title: Key takeaways from Jimmy Kimmel's first show since suspension
items.standfirst: "Jimmy Kimmel Live!" went back on the air Tuesday night, but about a third of the U.S. didn't see it as ABC affiliates owned by Nexstar and Sinclair continued their preemptions of the show. Brian Steinberg, senior TV editor for Variety, joins "The Takeout" to break down the key moments from Kimmel's return.
items.content: "Jimmy Kimmel Live!" went back on the air Tuesday night, but about a third of the U.S. didn't see it as ABC affiliates owned by Nexstar and Sinclair continued their preemptions of the show. Brian Steinberg, senior TV editor for Variety, joins "The Takeout" to break down the key moments from Kimmel's return.

items.title: Nexstar, joining Sinclair, will preempt Jimmy Kimmel’s late night show
items.standfirst: The broadcasting group will effectively pull Kimmel’s show from more than 30 ABC affiliates as the program is set to resume airing Tuesday night.
items.content: Nexstar Media Group will continue to preempt “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” on its ABC affiliates, the company said Tuesday, effectively pulling the late-night show from dozens of local stations as the comedian prepares to make his return to the airwaves. The company noted it would “monitor” the show as it returns to ABC, but said its stations would “focus on continuing to produce local news and other programming relevant to their respective markets.” The move makes Nexstar the second broadcasting company to preempt the show, following suit after the Sinclair Broadcasting Group announced Monday it would not air the talk program on its nearly 40 ABC affiliates. “We made a decision last week to preempt ‘Jimmy Kimmel Live!’ following what ABC referred to as Mr. Kimmel’s ‘ill-timed and insensitive’ comments at a critical time in our national discourse,” the company wrote in a statement Tuesday. “We stand by that decision pending assurance that all parties are committed to fostering an environment of respectful, constructive dialogue in the markets we serve.” Nexstar, the country’s largest local broadcasting group, owns roughly 30 ABC affiliates across cities like Nashville, Tenn., New Orleans and Salt Lake City. Sinclair also owns dozens of affiliates, including the ABC station serving Washington and its suburbs. ABC parent Disney announced Monday it would resume airing “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” after deciding to suspend the show last week to “avoid further inflaming a tense situation at an emotional moment for our country.” The show’s suspension sparked a flood of criticism from lawmakers and party leaders across the aisle, citing concerns about censorship — particularly after Federal Communications Commission Chair Brendan Carr threatened to look into affiliates because of the comedian’s comments. Nexstar is currently seeking a merger with Tegna, which requires FCC approval. “We have spent the last days having thoughtful conversations with Jimmy, and after those conversations, we reached the decision to return the show on Tuesday,” Disney's statement on Monday read.

ai_summary: "Jimmy Kimmel Live!" returned to the air after a suspension.
ABC affiliates owned by Nexstar and Sinclair preempted the show.
Nexstar is pulling Kimmel's show from over 30 ABC affiliates.
The show resumed airing on Tuesday night.
The show's return was analyzed by a senior TV editor.
